DraggingSurrogate Class Reference

#include <DraggingSurrogate.h>

Inheritance diagram for DraggingSurrogate:

List of all members.

Detailed Description

A dragging surrogate draws a dragged object (event target, list field row, etc.) next to the pointer, while dragging it.

Also defines the pointer targets while dragging over a possible and an unsupporting event target. Dragging surrogates are created by the source event target when the dragging starts, and will be deleted when dragging ends.

See also:
EventTarget

Constructor & Destructor Documentation

virtual ~DraggingSurrogate (   )  [protected, virtual]
 

Destroys the dragging surrogate.

DraggingSurrogate (  Vector  offset,
PointerType *  supportingPointerType = NULL,
PointerType *  unsupportingPointerType = NULL
)  [protected]
 

Creates a new dragging surrogate.

Parameters:
offset The offset of the surrogate relative to the pointer. This value is calculated when the dragging starts, and can be used when drawing the surrogate.
supportingPointerType The pointer type to show when dragging over an event target that supports dropping of the currently dragged object. NULL (which is the default) shows the skin's default dragging pointer type.
unsupportingPointerType The pointer type to show when dragging over an event target that does not support dropping of the currently dragged object. NULL (which is the default) shows the skin's default impossible pointer type.

DraggingSurrogate (   ) 
 

Creates a new dragging surrogate.

Member Function Documentation

DraggingSurrogate* createDefault (   )  [static]
 

Helper to easily creates a default dragging surrogate (using the default skin pointer types).

virtual void draw (  DrawingContext &  context  )  [virtual]
 

Draws the dragging surrogate next to the pointer, using the offset.

By default, draws nothing. This is useful to define the pointer types, only.

Parameters:
context The drawing context that specifies the surface and clipping rectangle for the drawing operation.

void* getModel (   )  [inherited]
 

Returns the application (or game) defined data.

Typically, there is an object that contains application data that corresponds to this graphical element. This object (or raw data) is stored here. Glaziery will not perform any operation on it, but you can use it to identify application objects for given event targets (such as components).

Returns:
The application (or game) defined data.

Vector getOffset (   ) 
 

Returns the offset of the surrogate relative to the pointer.

This value is calculated when the dragging starts, and can be used when drawing the surrogate.

Returns:
The surrogate drawing offset.

SkinData* getSkinData (   )  [inherited]
 

Returns the skin specific settings and other skin data.

The skin data is managed by the skin. If you want to implement a skin independent application (or game), do not use this object outside the skin. However, if you know which skin is in use and you require to read or write special property, you may cast this object to the respective type. This object may be NULL, if the skin does not need to store any data.

Returns:
The skin specific settings and other skin data.
Note:
If the object is not null when the component is destroyed, then the skin data is automatically destroyed.

virtual PointerType* getSupportingPointerType (   )  [virtual]
 

Returns the pointer type to show when dragging over an event target that supports dropping of the currently dragged object.

NULL (which is the default) shows the skin's default dragging pointer type.

Note:
Override this method to provide a dynamic pointer type. The default implementation returns the value specified in the constructor.
Returns:
The supporting pointer type.

virtual PointerType* getUnsupportingPointerType (   )  [virtual]
 

Returns the pointer type to show when dragging over an event target that does not support dropping of the currently dragged object.

NULL (which is the default) shows the skin's default impossible pointer type.

Note:
Override this method to provide a dynamic pointer type. The default implementation returns the value specified in the constructor.
Returns:
The unsupporting pointer type.

void GlazieryObject::destructor (  void *  model  )  [static, inherited]
 

Destructor function for the setModel() method, when setting a model that is a glaziery object itself.

Parameters:
model The model to be destroyed.
See also:
setModel()

virtual void onCanceled (  EventTarget *  draggedObject  )  [virtual]
 

Handles the event that the drag-drop operation is canceled.

This may happen when using the cancel key (ESC on Windows systems) or when the Desktop's cancelDragging() method is called.

Parameters:
draggedObject The event target that has been dragged.
See also:
Desktop::cancelDragging()

SpecialEvent::EVENT_CANCEL

virtual void onDragMove (  EventTarget *  draggedObject,
const Vector &  startPosition,
const Vector &  lastPosition,
const Vector &  currentPosition
)  [virtual]
 

Handles the event that the pointer is moved during a dragging operation.

Parameters:
draggedObject The event target that has been dragged.
startPosition The absolute position where the dragging started.
lastPosition The absolute position before the last move step.
currentPosition The new absolute position.

virtual void onDropped (  EventTarget *  draggedObject,
EventTarget *  dropTarget,
Vector  relativePosition,
bool  option1,
bool  option2
)  [virtual]
 

Handles the event that a dragging operation successfully ended.

This is when a dragging operation is in progress and the primary pointer button has been released.

Parameters:
draggedObject The event target that has been dragged.
dropTarget The event target where the object has been dropped. This may be, among others, the desktop.
relativePosition The relative position within the drop target. If the dropTarget is the desktop, this is the absolute pointer position.
option1 Whether the option button 1 is currently pressed, e.g. on Windows systems, this is the SHIFT key.
option2 Whether the option button 2 is currently pressed, e.g. on Windows systems, this is the CTRL key.

void setModel (  void *  model,
void(*  modelDestructor)(void *model) = NULL
)  [inherited]
 

Sets the application (or game) defined data.

Typically, there is an object that contains application data that corresponds to this graphical element. This object (or raw data) is stored here. Glaziery will not perform any operation on it, but you can use it to identify application objects for given event targets (such as components).

Parameters:
model The application (or game) defined data.
modelDestructor An optional static method that is called, whenever the glaziery object is destroyed or when a new model is set. Specify this function only, if the model must be destroyed by this glaziery object, i.e. the object "owns" the model. If the model is a glaziery object itself, you may use the GlazieryObject::destructor() function.
See also:
destructor()

void setOffset (  Vector  offset  )  [protected]
 

The offset of the surrogate relative to the pointer.

This value is calculated when the dragging starts, and can be used when drawing the surrogate.

Parameters:
offset The offset of the surrogate relative to the pointer.

virtual void setSkinData (  SkinData *  skinData  )  [virtual, inherited]
 

Sets the skin specific settings and other skin data.

The skin data is managed by the skin. If you want to implement a skin independent application (or game), do not use this object outside the skin. However, if you know which skin is in use and you require to read or write special property, you may cast this object to the respective type. This object may be NULL, if the skin does not need to store any data.

Parameters:
skinData The skin specific settings and other skin data.
Note:
If the object is not null when the component is destroyed, then the skin data is automatically destroyed.

Any previously set skin data is automatically destroyed.

Reimplemented in Component.

void setSupportingPointerType (  PointerType *  supportingPointerType  ) 
 

Sets the pointer type to show when dragging over an event target that supports dropping of the currently dragged object.

NULL (which is the default) shows the skin's default dragging pointer type.

Parameters:
supportingPointerType The supporting pointer type.

void setUnsupportingPointerType (  PointerType *  unsupportingPointerType  ) 
 

Sets the pointer type to show when dragging over an event target that does not support dropping of the currently dragged object.

NULL (which is the default) shows the skin's default impossible pointer type.

Parameters:
unsupportingPointerType The supporting pointer type.

virtual bool supportsDropping (  EventTarget *  draggedObject,
EventTarget *  dropTarget,
Vector  relativePosition
)  [virtual]
 

Returns whether the dragging surrogate supports dropping on a given event target.

By default, dropping is not supported at any position.

Parameters:
draggedObject The event target that is dragged.
dropTarget The event target where the object may be dropped. This may be, among others, the desktop.
relativePosition The relative position within the drop target. If the dropTarget is the desktop, this is the absolute pointer position.
Returns:
Whether the event target supports dropping of the dragged object at the position.
See also:
getOrigin()

virtual String toString (   )  [virtual, inherited]
 

Returns a string reprensentation of this object.

Returns:
The string representation.
